makers.displaydate: born 1961, New York, NY; active Princeton, NJ
makers.displaymaker: David Maisel, born 1961, New York, NY; active Princeton, NJ

texts.textentryhtml:
Gifted by Joshua R. Slocum, Class of 1998, and Sara T. Slocum
to Princeton University Art Museum, October 2023.

Fascinated by the ways X-rays flatten objects into two dimensions, Maisel mined the Getty Conservation Center’s archive for X-rays of statues (GM in the title stands for Getty Museum), photographed them, and manipulated the results in Photoshop so their tone matched that of early silver gelatin photographs. This image depicts a bust by the sculptor Joseph Chinard of Madame Récamier, a French socialite and muse to many artists of the Parisian salon. Mapping both the inner and outer surfaces of the subject, the X-ray confounds our perception of space, depth, and scale. As the artist explains: “The X-ray . . . reveals losses, replacements, methods of construction, and internal trauma that may not be visible to the naked eye.” At Princeton, Maisel (Class of 1984) was a student of Peter C. Bunnell, professor, curator of photography, and Art Museum director.

Comparative illustration: Joseph Chinard (1756–1813), Bust of Juliette Récamier (1777–1849), ca. 1801–2. The J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles
